reviews.review_msg: This is my second course with him. Hes so helpful, and nice, and he makes all these resources available to students. You can tell he really wants you to succeed. If youre taking this class ever again with him, do the policy paper, hes a policy pro. :) great tA!
He talks so much and he thinks he's inspirational. He also tries really hard to be cool. Class is really easy tho

Martin is by far the best prof I have ever had, everything he says is incredibly insightful and fascinating.  Anyone who thinks that his lectures are off topic obviously isn't paying much attention to him or to the course, because he takes issues that you were supposed to have read about and elaborates on them and offers a deeper insight.

Gives a lot of examples which makes some of the dry stuff more interesting. Genuinely wants his students to do good and is very specific about what is required from this course. Study for exams but have a lot of examples on hand to show your understanding and look out for the questions in readings and slides as he slips them in there.

All i remember from the first half of the semester was "ideological realism" lol. He gave lots of TV show examples and related them to the material but NEVER did any slides/notes. Students also had to review an article/per week to summarize but honestly I didn't get anything out of that and would rather receive special notes to prepare for exam

unclear and sometimes hard to understand in lecture, but he is clear in what is important and what to study for midterm. I took this in the summer and I believe it was Anis's first time teaching this course, and our midterm was open web/book and the exam is take home as well. He had guidance from Jody Baker and he even came in for a guest lecture.

If you take the time to talk to him and really understand what the assignment is about, he is not a hard marker.  He's actually a really great guy and is very helpful with questions and assignments.  Excellent at leading meaningful discussions.

Roy is an extremely hard marker - I had him as a TA. That's the only con to having him. He is a very good TA, though. Very willing to give help and spend extra time one-on-one. He made the material interesting and encouraged alot of great discussions.

Doris has very controversial teaching methods. She has ppt notes but refuses to send them out b/c, as she says, "the pictures are mine and I do not want them out." Students have resorted to taking digital pictures of slides in lecture b/c she goes too fast. Finally, she's monotone. I've fallen asleep several times. AVOID HER IF YOU CAN!
You haven't lived unless you've taken a class with Roman.
I hear he's better in other courses.  But his style of teaching CMNS 220 was absolutely terrible - highly disorganized overly demanding.

he's an extremely funny guy but carries such boring lectures; maybe it's b/c he change 220 into a TV-critical writing course and he seems like hez talkin about some crap that he doesn't even wanna tlk about.
roman has the ability to be funny and make people laugh. but he went off topic almost 3/4 of all lectures this semester which made it really boring. didn't feel like anything was learned

a strong personality so you either like him or ya don't....i did - Roman is REAL, and a real relief compared to most in the idealistic world of Academia...his real-life experience was refreshing and well-needed in the CMNS department!
Lectures are extremely boring. Talks way too much about his previous experience in the TV business. Uninteresting and poor sense of humour.
Talks out of his ass. Lectures were totally irrelevant. Seemed like a really nice guy but I think he secretly wants to be a stand up comedian not a professor.

She knows her stuff but is not a very engaging speaker. She doesn't have control of the class and her weird temper is distracting. TA for this class didn't help. She was horrible, named Yan. Proficiency in the English language would be appreciated.

Doesn't allow electronic devices in class, and will KICK OUT STUDENTS for something as small as texting in class. Treats students like children, by providing extremely strict 'guidelines' for each assignment. Heavy, heavy workload,was a difficult course, despite the interest i had in the subject.
Zoe is very interested in all of the subject matter she teaches. I had her for 223 as well; same deal.

Zoe is by far the best professor Ive ever had, even amongst other departments. She is very helpful in and outside of lecture, and her lectures are always interesting. Through her obvious passion for her work she can make any dry material very interesting. Definately an amazing woman.
Zoe is awesome. She is my favorite communication proffessor. I want to take so more classes she is teaching.

I'm not sure about the other classes that she's teaching, but this CMNS 220 (Understanding Television) class is quite boring and demanding. Make sure you study your midterm because it isn't going to be easy.

ZOE IS SO HOT.  She rocked my little heterosexual world. She's got an oomph that transcends all gender boundaries.  Oh... yeah.. and the class was fun as well.  A definite must-attend course, especially with Zoe up there lecturing.
No Comments
She is a great prof. One of my favourite.
Very fun, knows what she's talking about but does get quick & tricky sometimes... overall, very cool prof~
No Comments
overall the course is hard... but the prof is very generous.  very nice ~
Great prof who actually cares about his students. 10/10

Ask pretty much any communications student and they will say the same thing: "Take a class with Jody". He's got lots of energy, is pretty funny, and the lectures for CMNS 220 were honestly pretty entertaining. He genuinely seems like he wants his students to succeed in his courses, and is willing to reward you if you do well.

Great lecturer, I never skipped a class because I actually really looked forward to them! He's funny, interesting and the main ideas for the course are very clear. If you show that you've done the readings, you'll do great! Definitely hope to take another course with him again.

I've taken 3 classes with jody (cmns 220, 223, 130), and I think most of his classes are the same in terms of grading. Basically, all papers/assignments of any sort have one goal: demonstrate you've done the readings. Quote-drop like crazy in your essays, have a decent thesis, and you're golden. His finals always seem to be take-home/online exams,

Great enthusiasm, he shows a lot of interest in the courses he teaches. All his assignments are clear and he lays out what he expects from everyone one day one. Would definitely take more courses with him.
All I have to say is that I wish he taught more classes! Very good prof. Explains everything you'd ever need to know and he's hilarious

While he doesn't use slides (I really love slides...) and it's an adjustment at first if you can figure out a way to take notes lectures are fine. Final is fair and no surprises-- TA sent out a 'what to focus on' which was pretty much the final. Pay attention in class/write down what he is saying and you're good.

He's very friendly. Everyone loves him. His lectures were insightful as he talked a lot about Western TV shows, etc.  However, he doesn't give out presentation slides (he doesn't even use slides). He only talks in class.

Jody is a very helpful professor, at some point he's even more helpful than he's TA. Make sure you do all the reading, it's very important if you want to pass this class. The class was interesting,  DO NOT miss the lecture or you'll fail for sure

Jody Baker is one of the most interesting professors at SFU and I had so much fun taking this class. The lectures offer some interesting perspective on analyzing TV. Although there are two papers, they're manageable - however, grading will depend on your TA. Jody has a stress-free exam policy, which is always a plus.

Excellent prof. Jody is passionate, hilarious, inspirational. His lectures are anything but boring, and his grading criteria is crystal clear, he talks about how to write the paper in lecture. If you talk to him about your topic, he'll personally recommend a list of references for you. Great prof, entertaining, caring, interesting, would take again

Just a Great Prof. I talked to him twice. When I walked in, I had no idea how to write the paper. He was patient and he analyzed the material (you gotta have something first though) with (for) you. You can take all the time you need, hes happy that you come to him. He is extremely helpful. Final can be tough for some (3 short essay in 2 hours).
Amazing teacher, shows a ton of videos like the daily show, bachelor, and americas next top model. Gets you into the lecture. Doesn't believe in tests. Really great guy
Friendly knowledgeable teacher, but bad class for students who aren't auditory learners.  He talks very quickly and doesn't use any slides so lectures can be very hard to follow.
I took a course a few years ago and liked his class a lot. really fun!
Easy class, but pretty boring. I felt Jody was unorganized and rambled on a lot. But he's a funny guy.

I have taken two of Jody's classes. Hands down the best prof I've ever had. He was so interested in the course content, which made learning the material much more enjoyable. Humorous and personable. Always up for discussion and available for help. Final exam is open book/open laptop. It's clear he wants you to succeed!

Jody is a fantastic prof and has made CMNS 220 my favorite class yet. He speaks very clearly and his presentation slides are always helpful and the tv show examples he uses are very interesting. Papers and midterms are demanding but can be done easily if you give enough time. I am definitely looking for more classes that Jody teaches.

My favorite communications prof yet. Jody was extremely helpful, had very interesting lectures and it was very apparent that he cared about what he was teaching, and cared about our succcess in his class. The final was great and worked to the students advantage.

This prof is awesome. I was hoping to take a few more classes with him at SFU... but what's this I see? - SFU hasn't got him back for the upcoming semester. I hope that this is some seasonal mistake on SFU's part.
Wonderful professor, his stories and jokes were funny/cool!

Excellent professor, one of the best I've ever had! He is extremely excited about the course content and sets up workshops outside the lecture and puts in online for everyone to listen.  This was very helpful and he truly wants his students to learn.

Jody just came from the University of Pittsburgh and this was the first class he taught at SFU. Great prof, as he had lots of insightful comments and thoughts to share. He's an easygoing guy, and really allowed me to enjoy the class. I would gladly take another class with Jody!
